awd_titl_txt: Optimal Control in Coupled Systems with Moving Interfaces
awd_abstract_narration:
This project addresses the control of turbulence inside fluid flow in the case of free boundary interaction between a viscous fluid and a moving and deforming elastic body.  Reducing and controlling turbulence flow is particularly relevant in the design of small-scale unmanned aircrafts and morphing aircraft wings (e.g. improving the flight of a robobee), and is also of great interest in the medical community (for example, blood flow in a stenosed or stented artery).  The proposed problem presents new challenges since it treats the case of a moving and deforming elastic body coupled with a viscous fluid, building on the existing literature on control problems in fluid-structure interactions, which is predominantly focused on the assumption of small but rapid oscillations of the solid body, and therefore assumes that the common interface is static.  Due to the presence of the free boundary and the fully nonlinear coupled system, the issue of existence and uniqueness of an optimal control will involve strategies from sensitivity and shape differentiability analysis, on top of techniques from control theory of partial differential equations and well-posedness analysis for fluid-structure interactions.  Therefore, the project will be of interest to a broad mathematical and engineering audience.  

Mathematically, the proposed research will lead to: (i) the construction of quasilinear theory arising in Navier-Stokes equations coupled with waves, (ii) the development of the theory of strong shape derivatives for hyperbolic problems with non-smooth Neumann boundary conditions, which is challenging due to the failure of the Lopatinski condition, and (iii) the study of well-posedness analysis for the first linear model of fluid-elasticity interaction that takes into account the common interface and its curvatures, which are critical for a correct physical interpretation of the coupling. The project will launch new research in the field, since the approach and the techniques introduced for the minimization of drag in the fluid-elasticity interaction can be adjusted and used to investigate inverse or control problems in many other free boundary coupled physical systems, and with different types of controls. 

The principal investigator has partnered with the North Carolina Museum of Natural Sciences in an effort to create a "Math Day at the Museum", in order to promote and present her research to a broad audience, showcase students' research through posters and presentations, and encourage the participation of women and minorities in the study of math. During these events, the principal investigator will give public presentations on her research, develop and set up demonstrations of real world phenomena illustrating applications of partial differential equations and their control.  In addition, the principal investigator plans to promote women and minorities in math, by involving several student groups from North Carolina State University, including the Association for Women in Mathematics, Women in Science and Engineering, and the Society of African American Physical and Mathematical Sciences.

por.por_cntn:
This project advances the theory of  PDE-constrained optimization and  optimal control problems governed by fluid-structure interactions (FSI). FSI are described by incompressible, viscous fluids that either flow within elastic bodies or surround elastic structures that move and deform inside them. FSI are ubiquitous in  medical and engineering applications, ranging from  blood flow in stenosed arteries and heart valve dynamics to the design of small-scale unmanned aircrafts and morphing aircraft wings. Problems of interest consist of (i) minimizing turbulence in blood flow inside a stenosed or stented artery, (ii) controlling the behavior of the FSI to achieve a given target fluid velocity or pressure, (iii) minimizing the hydro-elastic pressure on the interface between the two environments, and so on. Existing literature on control problems in FSI is predominantly focused on the assumption of small but rapid oscillations of the solid body, so that the common interface may be assumed static. This project focused on the issue of reducing turbulence inside the flow in the case of a moving and deforming elastic body coupled with a viscous fluid, and established the first existence result of an optimal control for this problem in the framework of the available local wellposedness theory. If the initial configuration is regular, then a class of sufficiently smooth control inputs contains an element that minimizes, within the control class, the vorticity of the fluid flow around a moving and deforming elastic solid. As part of the sensitivity analysis associated with control problems in FSI, we worked with new linearized models that did not ignore the geometry of the problem and took into account the curvature and the boundary acceleration of the free and moving common interface. Therefore, these linear models were quite different than the classical couplings of linear Stokes flows and linear elasticity, and showcased the role of the geometry of the problem. In this project, we provided an analysis of existence and uniqueness of solution, as well as feedback stabilization, for the linearized coupled systems mentioned above and highlighted the role of the fluid viscosity in ensuring the existence of solutions. These new linear fluid-elastiticy models are also essential in the study of stability of equilibrium states in hydroelasticity, which is an important design aspect of complex industrial systems and understanding of biological processes. Finally, we provided a complete description of the adjoint sensitivity system, which is necessary in the derivation of optimality conditions for the control, thus providing a characterization of the control and opening the pathway for derivative based optimization algorithms in free and moving boundary FSI.

In this project, we also considered nonlinear poro-visco-elastic models with applications in biomechanics.  We provided the first result for existence of solutions for nonlinear poro-elastic and poro-visco-elastic models with permeability depending nonlinearly on dilation, and no simplifying assumptions on the domain boundary and the associated boundary conditions. This work extends all previous results on analysis of nonlinear poro-visco-elastic models. We complemented the theoretical results with numerical simulations based on a novel dual mixed hybridized finite element discretization. The results are highly relevant in the case of the Lamina Cribrosa (LC) in the eye, a poro-visco-elastic tissue at the base of the optic nerve head, whose biomechanics is believed to play an important role in the development of glaucoma. We identified the presence of viscoelasticity in the solid phase as a major determinant in the behavior of the solutions, suggesting that the lack of viscoelasticity may increase the susceptibility of the tissue to localized damage as volumetric sources of linear momentum and/or boundary sources of traction experience sudden changes in time. Based on the analysis, our novel hypothesis is that physiological changes in intraocular pressure induce pathological changes in the hemodynamics of the LC tissue if the viscoelasticity provided by the collagen fibers is not intact. 

During the course of the project, nine papers were published in refereed journals. The PI mentored one post doc, four graduate students, and two undergraduate students at NC State University. The PI gave twenty three presentations on results related to this project, and her students gave twenty eight talks and two poster presentations (at national and international conferences).
